Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Big Data to Analyze Maritime Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Maritime conflict has been on the rise globally, with hotspots across the world's regions. Despite growing coverage in the news media, among think tanks, and great attention from policy makers and politicians, there is limited systematic data on conflict incidents in maritime regions. This project will fill two important gaps. First, it will generate a multi-faceted dataset on maritime conflict that will be shared publicly for use by scholars and journalists. Second, although theorists have offered many competing accounts for what to expect in the realm of maritime conflict, there have yet to be any compelling empirical investigations of what has taken place in the past decade. This project will develop data collection techniques that will be applicable to a range of maritime conflict-affected regions, which also have substantial national security implications.<br/><br/>Social scientists have increasingly turned to data-driven approaches to answer important questions regarding international security. Within the world of conflict research, comprehensive datasets have played a critical role in advancing scientific knowledge (e.g. AidData, COW, ACLED). Thus far, however, there has been limited systematic empirical analysis of maritime conflict; a major hurdle is a lack of data. In this project, the PIs acquire and consolidate comprehensive data on maritime incidents and make substantial progress toward empirically testing and resolving competing theories for how maritime conflict may play out over the next decade. The project refines prevailing theories of power transition, taking into account the slow but steady change in maritime capabilities of superpowers as well as the growing economic and political interdependence among nation-states since the end of the Cold War, to generate new testable hypotheses. The analysis utilizes the overlapping EEZ zones and territorial waters, variation in off-shore natural resource distribution, and changes in domestic politics to test the proposed hypotheses. The data will be made publicly available and legible to other social scientists so that experts can replicate it for their own research purposes.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we collected, analyzed and geo-coded conflict events in the South China Sea from 2012-2020. This research was inspired by the rising level of policy and public interest in China's growing presence in the South China Sea and our lack of systematic situational awareness about the conditions there. In the end we have produced a publicly-available dataset that can be accessed at scsdi.org/data. Students, journalists and reasearchers are already using the data to understand the stay of play in the South China Sea.

The SCSDI project began with the hiring of five research assistants from Southeast Asia to begin collecting and processing news-reported event data from the South China Sea region. Throughout 2020, we worked closely with our RAs to develop a collection matrix, coding rules, data management process and training on key research norms and practices (as an aside, three of the five RAs from this stage of the project have gone on to start PhDs in top programs in the US, in part based on their experience with this project). The event data collection process yielded 1,241 event datapoints from 2010 to 2020.

Geo-locating the incidents was a challenge, because (as it turns out) many ships in the westen Pacific do not have reliable IMO/MMSI numbers or their safety radio transponders lose connections (called AIS, these transponders are often used to track ships from satelites and shore stations). As a result, the research team had to manually code about 75% of the incidents. 

In the end, we learned that conflict incidents are indeed on the rise in the South China Sea, and since 2012 Chinese vessels are in involved in a growing part of them. We also learned that clashes between Southeast Asian countries' vessels is a large and often underreported part of the story. The attached images show some data trends over time.
